SENT.plain: The management of colorectal cancer patients with liver metastases is a common clinical problem
If patients can undergo resection of liver metastases, long-term survival can be achieved
Converting a patient from unresectable to resectable, however, remains a major challenge
The majority of patients who undergo liver resection for colorectal metastases recur; therefore, adjuvant treatment following resection should be considered
Emerging literature suggests that hepatic arterial infusion (HAI) can be combined with systemic chemotherapy
Both therapies can be given at nearly full doses, thus improving resectability and outcomes for patients with colorectal liver metastases
HAI plus systemic can also be a useful option for adjuvant treatment after hepatic resection
